__data__.text:
1.1 Background

The Risk Management team at Bank Muscat and Meethaq Islamic Banking has been utilizing Moody’s Analytics software solution products to enhance the credit decision-making process for both SME and Large Corporate loans. Initially, the bank implemented Moody’s Risk Analyst, which was later replaced by the Credit Lens product in 2020. The current version, CreditLens 5.20.12.1 Build 98, was implemented in September 2020 and is set to be decommissioned by December 2024.

 2.0 Project Scope

 2.1 In Scope

 2.1.a. Entities & Customer Segments

1. CreditLens Upgrade is applicable for both
1. Bank Muscat
2. Meethaq Islamic Banking
2. Credit Analysis will be performed for customers in these categories
1. Small and Medium Enterprises – With Audited Financials
2. Small and Medium Enterprises – Without Audited Financials
3. Large Corporates
4. HNWI – High Networth Individual

 2.1.b. Upgrade

The upgrades listed below are expected to be a part of this project.

__data__.text:
2.1.c. Application Integration

CreditLens upgrade requires the following systems to be integrated

| S. No | System Name | Purpose of Integration | Integration Method & Security |
| ----- | ----------- | ---------------------- | ----------------------------- |

Active Directory

For authentication of users with Active Directory credentials

 Credit Lens - UI

Users accessing the UI for capturing customer details

Application is configured with HTTPS with the bank provided certificate.

 SIEM

Security Incident and Event Monitoring system

N/A

 NTP Server

Network Time Protocol (NTP) is a protocol used to synchronize computer clock times in a network server

Time synchronization is client-server programs that run on computers using UDP Protocol & authenticated.

 PAM

To access production Linux console

Domain authentication over https

To access user data aggregation for

 IAM

Periodic user details and privileges review

JDBC connectivity with TLS 1.2

 2.2 Out of Scope

1. Segments other than SME, Large Corporates & High Networth Individuals.
2. Credit exposure limit lesser than OMR 100,000/-.

3.0 Solution Functionalities

1. The Risk Management team utilizes the CreditLens application to perform Credit Assessments for new and top-up loans within the SME, Large Corporate, and High Net Worth Individuals segments, specifically for exposures exceeding OMR 100,000.
2. Credit Analysis requests are submitted by Account Relationship Managers (ARMs) on behalf of bank clients who are seeking new or supplementary loans.
3. The Credit Risk team enters pertinent data from the Balance Sheet, Income Statement, and Cash Flow Statement to conduct a Quantitative Analysis, supplemented by a Questionnaire to aid in the quantitative evaluation process.
4. The results of this analysis guide the corporate teams in making decisions regarding the approval of new loans or the issuance of top-up loans.
5. The Credit Lens upgrade represents a like-to-like implementation in which all data pertaining to the current version, including information on obligors, financial spreading, credit models, and rating details, will be transferred to the upgraded version.
6. The enhanced CreditLens application is anticipated to offer a centralized platform for users to store, share, and access customer information, facilitating comprehensive life-cycle management from initial creation to approval, while also accommodating changes in the customer's financial circumstances over time.

 3.1 Input Data & Analysis

The account relationship manager is responsible for to collect all relevant information from the customer and provide the same to the rating analyst in the Risk Management. The information includes:

1. Quantitative Analysis –
1. Latest Audited financial for existing customers,
2. Last 3 years audited financials for new customers.
3. The audited financial statements encompass the annual report of the client, which includes the
1. Chairman's report,
2. Auditor's report,
3. Balance sheet,
4. Profit and Loss account, and
5. Notes to the accounts, among other documents.
4. Audited Financial reports must be not older than 120 days from the close of the financial year.
5. An authorized audited financial report is required for all clients with exposure limits exceeding OMR 250,000 within our bank or OMR 500,000 or more within the broader banking system in Oman.
6. Quantitative Analysis is driven by financial factors like Profitability, Capital Structure, Liquidity / Cash Flows, Size, Trading Accounts, Sales Growth etc.
7. In case if the customer fails to submit the Audited Financial Statements within the stipulated time all facilities of such customers must be frozen till the customer complies.
2. Qualitative Analysis –

1. Questionnaires

1. A questionnaire focused on subjective feedback, encompassing inquiries about Account Conduct, Management Quality, Industry Perspectives, and various business-related information.
2. SME – Questionnaire – without financial – applicable for SME’s with exposure limits below OMR 250000/- (Refer to Annexure 1).
3. SME – Questionnaire – with financial – applicable for SME’s with exposure limits greater than OMR 250000/- (Refer to Annexure 2).
4. MRA – Questionnaire – Corporate – for large corporates (Refer to Annexure 3).
5. High Networth Individual Questionnaire (Refer Annexure 4).

 3. Analysis Types

1. Both Qualitative and Quantitative Assessment is required for
1. Large Corporates &
2. SME with Financials.
2. Only Qualitative assessment is required for
1. SME without Financials &
2. High Networth Individuals.

 4. Final Score

1. Quantitative and qualitative results are finally aggregated into an overall score and the counterparty is finally assigned a Probability of Delinquency.

 3.2 Criteria for Rating

1. The relationship manager evaluates the credit approval for a new customer at the time the credit application is submitted.
2. Existing customers undergoing an annual review of their extended facilities, which is subsequently followed by the renewal of their credit limits.
3. Credit Analysis is applicable for SME & Large Corporates with minimum exposure limit of OMR 100000/-.
4. For exposure limit less than OMR 250000/- financial documents (Authorised Auditor Report) are not required.
5. For exposure amounts exceeding OMR 250,000, Audited Financial Documents must be furnished.

 3.3 Entity Search

1. Members of the authorized credit risk team at the bank must be able to access the upgraded Credit Risk portal using their valid Active Directory credentials.
2. Users from the bank should be able to navigate to the Entity Search screen, where they can view all entities that have previously undergone Credit Analysis, presented in a tabular format.
3. The information listed must include but not limited to
1. Entity ID – Unique identifier for the entity,
2. Long Name – Full name of the entity,
3. Alias – Alternative or the abbreviated name of the entity,
4. Entity Type – Classification of company,
5. Entity Source – Origin of the entity creation,

4.

All columns should include sorting options to allow users to arrange the data according to their preferences.

 5.

The system must also provide search filters for staff to locate and retrieve specific entities. The search criteria should encompass, but not be limited to, the following filters.

- a. Long Name – Full name of the entity,
- b. Alias Name – Alternative or the abbreviated name of the entity,
- c. Entity Type - Classification of company,
- d. Country of Incorporation – Country where the entity was established,
- e. Primary Banking Officer – Name of the ARM or sales officer,
- f. Primary Credit Officer - Name of the Credit Officer who performed the credit analysis for that entity,
- g. Entity Source – Origin of the entity creation,
- h. LAS ID – LAS ID from system.

 6.

The system should offer the following functionalities for bank user, including but not limited to:

- a. Search Button – To initiate search based on the specific filter criteria,
- b. Clear – To reset the entered filter criteria or the results of the search,
- c. Add New Entity – To create new entity,
- d. Download – To download the list of entities displayed,
- e. Search History – To access the most recently used filter criteria.

 7.

The system must display a list of entities that correspond to the specified search filters.

 8.

Bank users should have the capability to click on each individual item to access comprehensive information about each entity within the Entity Management Screen.

 3.4 Entity Creation

1. Authorized bank users should be able to navigate to the Create Entity section by clicking on the Add New Entity icon.
2. In the Create New Entity data entry screen, the bank user is required to enter key information for the entity being created, which includes, but is not limited to:

- a. Long Name – Full name of the entity (Mandatory Field),
- b. Alias –Alternative or the abbreviated name of the entity (Mandatory Field),
- c. Entity Type – Classification of company,
- d. Business portfolio / Banking Unit – Sourcing business unit,
- e. Credit Portfolio – Head office portfolio or any specific portfolio (Mandatory Field),
- f. Country of Incorporation – Country where the entity was established,
- g. Province / State of Incorporation – State / Province where the entity was established,
- h. CRM System ID – CRM lead ID.

3.

The system must provide the following functionalities for bank user, including but not limited to:

- a. Save – To save the inputted details for the new entity,
- b. Save and Add Another – To save the inputted details for the new entity and continue with the creation of additional entities,
- c. Cancel – To cancel the new entity creation process.

 4.

Upon saving, the newly created entity must be recorded in the system along with the basic details.

5.

Bank user must be able to input additional information for that entity by selecting it from Entity Search screen and subsequently should be able to access the Entity Information screen within the Entity Management screen.

 6.

Bank user must be able to input the information related to the company in the Entity Information module which include

- a. Basic Details – Bank user must be asked to input the basic details like
- i. Customer Details,
- ii. Organisation Details,
- iii. Officer Details,
- iv. Contact Details,
- v. Address Details and
- vi. Entity Group Details.
- b. Business Details – Bank user must be asked to input the business details like
- i. Business Legal Information,
- ii. Industry Information,
- iii. Connected Parties Information.
- c. Other optional information to be added includes
- i. Hierarchy Management,
- ii. Documents Management.

 6.a.i Basic Details – Customer Details

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to

- a. Entity Type (Non-Editable – Defaulted to Company),
- b. Long Name (Text Box – Mandatory Field),
- c. Alias (Text Box – Mandatory Field),
- d. Entity ID – To be auto populated by system based on sequence and must be unique.
- e. CRM System ID (Text Box),
- f. LAS ID# (Text Box),
- g. Other ID (Text Box),
- h. Legal Entity ID (Text Box),
- i. Tax ID (Text Box),
- j. Customer Since (Calendar Selection),
- k. Country of Incorporation (Dropdown Selection),
- l. Province / State of Incorporation (Dropdown Selection),
- m. Date of Incorporation (Calendar Selection),
- n. Registration Number (Text Box),
- o. On List (Dropdown list),
- p. Related Party (Checkbox),
- q. Description (Free Text).

 6.a.ii Basic Details – Organisation Details

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to

- a. Business Portfolio / banking Unit (Dropdown – Mandatory Field),
- b. Division (Dropdown),
- c. Credit Portfolio (Dropdown – Mandatory Field),
- d. Restricted Entry (Checkbox).

 6.a.iii Basic Details – Officer Details

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to

6.a.iv Basic Details – Contact Details

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to:

- Name,
- Salutation,
- Email,
- Mobile Number,
- Office Number,
- Fax Number.

 6.a.v Basic Details – Address Details

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to:

- Address Type,
- Address 1,
- Address 2,
- Country,
- State / Province / Region,
- City,
- Zip / Postal Code.

 6.a.vi Basic Details – Entity Details

Bank user needs to capture the entity details as well.

 6.b.i Business Details – Business legal Information

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to:

- Firm Type (Dropdown – Mandatory),
- Country of Risk (Dropdown – Mandatory),
- Risk Currency (Dropdown – Mandatory).

 6.b.ii Business Details – Industry Information

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to:

- Industry Classification (Dropdown),
- Add New
- Industry Code (Mandatory),
- Percentage (Mandatory),
- Primary.

 6.b.iii Business Details – Connected Parties

Bank user needs to capture the following information which includes but not limited to:

- Name,
- Role,
- Comment.

 7. Financial Analysis Setup

Bank user must also be able to setup the financial analysis for the entity:

- Template Information – Financial Information (Dropdown – Mandatory Field),
- Spreading Information –
- Target Currency (Dropdown),
- Inventory Accounting Method (Dropdown),
- Depreciation Method (Dropdown),
- Fiscal Year End Month (Dropdown),
- Revenue Accounting Method (Dropdown),
- Segment Type (Dropdown).
- Combine Information –

8. Enable Content Statement (Toggle Enable Disable)

Bank user must be able to input all necessary details and save the entity creation. Once saved, the entity information must be accessible when users search for, retrieve and view the details of the newly created entity.

 3.5 Quantitative Assessment

1. The Account Relationship Manager for Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs) or Large Corporations is tasked with collecting the necessary audited financial data from clients and submitting it to the credit risk team for financial assessment.
2. The financial documents required for this assessment include:
1. Existing Customers - Latest Audited Financial,
2. New Customer – Last three years Audited Financials.
3. Audited financial statements consist of the client's annual report, which features the Chairman’s report, Auditor’s report, Balance Sheet, Profit and Loss account, and related notes.
4. The quantitative module should be shaped by financial factors selected through expert panel insights and statistical analysis. The weighted interactions of these factors yield a quantitative score for the counterparty.
5. An authorized member of the Bank’s Credit Risk Management team must access the Financial Analysis module to enter the customer’s financial information.
6. Historical financial data for existing customers should be easily retrievable from the interface.
7. The authorized user must have the capability to view and modify the previous year's data if necessary.
8. The authorized user is obligated to input all pertinent information, which includes, but is not limited to:
1. Period - Denotes the number of months covered for that particular assessment column item,
2. Audit Method – Denotes if the financials are assessed by a Qualified or an Unqualified Auditor. (Mandatory Field)
3. Accountant – Denotes the auditing firm that has done the audit for the client.
4. Analyst – Denotes the name of the Risk Analyst from Credit Risk team who inputs the data into the system. (Mandatory Field)
5. Statement Type – Denotes the periodicity of the financial report,
6. Accounting Status – Denotes if it is reviewed or not reviewed,
7. Consolidation – Denotes if the report is consolidated report or not,
8. Currency – Denotes the currency in which the financial report is classified,
9. Reconcile To – Denotes the Financial period of the audit,
10. Total Assets – Auto populated summation of all the assets,
11. Total Liabilities & Networth– Auto populated summation of all the liabilities & Networth,
12. Bank authorised user must input further details like
1. Current Assets,
2. Non-Current Assets,
3. Current Liabilities,
4. Non-Current Liabilities,
5. Other Liabilities / Equity,
6. Networth / Owner’s Equity,
7. Income Expenses,
8. Other Comprehensive Income.

3.6 Qualitative Assessment

1. The Account Relationship Manager (ARM) is responsible for gathering and completing the relevant questionnaire that focuses on subjective inputs necessary for the Qualitative Assessment.
2. The ARM should compile the questionnaire using various information sources, including customer meetings, market data, and news articles.
3. The qualitative aspect features a scorecard designed to capture elements not addressed by the quantitative analysis, consisting of a series of questions organized by thematic categories.
4. The analyst is required to select from a list of predetermined responses for each question.
5. The individual scores are then aggregated according to their respective weights and transformed into a qualitative score that reflects the perceived risk level of the transaction.
6. The questionnaire encompasses inquiries related to account behaviour, management quality, industry outlook, and other business-related factors.
7. Each customer segment will have four distinct questionnaires tailored to their specific needs.
1. SME Questionnaire – Without Financial, (Refer Annexure 1),
2. SME Questionnaire – With Financial, (Refer Annexure 2),
3. MRA Questionnaire – Corporate. (Refer Annexure 3),
4. HNWI Questionnaire – High Networth Individuals (Refer Annexure 4).
8. The bank user should be able to access the Risk Grading Section, select the appropriate model, and create a new rating by updating the subjective information.
9. SME Questionnaire – Without Financial should include information like
1. Company Name,
2. Account Number,
3. Description of Business,
4. NAICS Code,
5. Year of Business Commencement,
6. Compiled By,
7. Detailed Objective Type Questions - Business –
1. Diversity of Products/Services,
2. Reputation with Stakeholders,
3. Obsolescence Risk,
4. Legal Form of Company,
5. Suitability of Business Location,
6. Competitive Position in the market,
7. Customer Concentration,
8. Years in Business,
9. Group Affiliations,

10. SME Questionnaire – With Financial should include information like

- a. Company Name,
- b. Account Number,
- c. Description of Business,
- d. NAICS Code,
- e. Year of Business Commencement,
- f. Compiled By,

 g. Detailed Objective Type Questions - Business –

- i. Diversity of Products/Services
- ii. Reputation with Stakeholders
- iii. Obsolescence Risk
- iv. Legal Form of Company
- v. Suitability of Business Location
- vi. Competitive Position in the market
- vii. Customer Concentration
- viii. Years in Business
- ix. Group Affiliations,
- x. Physical and Human Resources,
- xi. Years in Bank Relationship,

 h. Detailed Objective Type Questions - Management –

- i. Management Structure,
- ii. Track Record of Management,
- iii. Relevant Experience Management,
- iv. Owner Involvement in Business,
- v. Age of Management,
- vi. Management Strategy and planning,

 i. Detailed Objective Type Questions – Account Conduct –

- i. Repayment History,
- ii. Turnover in O/D Account in Past 12 months,
- iii. External Checking’s and References,

 11. MRA Questionnaire Corporate should include information like

Detailed Objective Type Questions

 Management Quality

 Management Organisation

1. Leadership
2. Structure
3. Planning
4. Teamwork
5. Information Quality

 Management Succession

1. Successor Preparation
2. Succession Plan

 Marketing Skill

1. Marketing Skill
2. Operations Skill
3. Financial Skill

 Management Charter

1. Commitment
2. Integrity

 Company Standing

 Reputation

1. Reputation with customer
2. Reputation with vendors
3. Reputation with employees

 Status

1. Ownership Involvement
2. Credit History
3. Risk of adverse events

 Capital Structure

1. Access to Capital

 Operations

1. Market Strength
2. Trading Area
3. Customer loyalty
4. Competitive Edge
5. Market Conditions
6. Threat of Substitutes

 Liquidity

1. Customer Quality
2. Debtor Accounting Risk
3. Stock Confidence
4. Customer Concentration
5. Credit Practices
6. Stock Liquidity

 High Networth Individuals (HNWI)

 Account Conduct

1. Repayment History

3.6 Data Entry

After all subjective information has been entered, the user should click on calculate and then model result to determine the final rating.

Bank user must be able to click Complete and then approve the rating.

 3.7 Reports Generation

1. Once both qualitative and quantitative data are entered, the system generates rating reports that indicate the likelihood of the borrower defaulting.
2. Financial Reports: Financial Reports should include but not limited to
- The standard balance sheet and income statement presentation, with options for reporting the full financial details or more condensed summary.
- An analysis of cash flows and ratios, along with comparisons to industry benchmarks.
- The report must present historical financial data, as well as both detailed and summary reports based on projected financial outcomes.
3. Qualitative Reports: Qualitative Reports should include but not limited to
- Automatically generated dynamic narrative analysis reports (smart-text) based on historical financial data, highlighting both positive and negative indicators, key questions, cash flow summaries, financial statement alerts, and a comprehensive Financial Performance Analysis report.
- For example, consultant reports should offer insightful commentary with key observations and questions regarding a company's declining profitability or provide detailed explanations identifying the main factors affecting the company's cash flow performance.
- The system administrator must have the ability to modify the parameters used in the rule engine for this automatically generated analysis text.
4. Please refer to Annexures 5, 6, and 7 for examples of the various reports generated based on the selections made.
5. The report will then be sent to the respective relationship manager for use in the credit application process.

6.

The system should maintain only one rating record for each customer for any given financial year.

 7.

If a customer receives multiple ratings, the existing record will be updated. The rating analyst will not challenge the subjective inputs provided by the relationship manager.

 8.

However, the system should generate alerts if the subjective inputs are inconsistent with the established criteria.

 9.

Corporate ratings must be revised annually.

 10.

Updates to the ratings should occur upon the receipt of the customer's annual audited financial statements, usually available within 120 days following the end of the financial year.

 11.

Customer ratings are to be maintained in the database.

 12.

Each customer is assigned a unique identification number, randomly generated by the rating system, to guarantee distinct ratings for every financial year.

 3.8 Migration & Reconciliation of Data

1. Migration - The bank expects that the current data will be seamlessly migrated from the existing version to the new version without any modifications in the following areas:
1. Data migration from the current database to the enhanced CreditLens (CL) database on the new server.
2. Archived data must also be migrated from the existing system to the upgraded CreditLens (CL) system.
3. The current user base, along with their access permissions, should also be migrated.
2. Reconciliation – Bank requires reconciliation to be performed to verify the completeness and accuracy of the migrated data
1. Technical DB Level – Reconciliation of Existing DB v/s New DB should be conducted for the following
1. Database Objects Count (Count of database objects based on the object types),
2. Database Table Structure which includes Column Attribute Modification, Columns Added, Columns Dropped (Table structure modification such as change in data type or data scale, addition of columns, dropping of columns).
2. Technical Data Reconciliation –
1. Row counts of tables from both versions to be taken and verified.
2. In case of mismatch between tables- Reason for the mismatch to be analysed and ascertained if it is Data Structure changes or introducing new tables or any other reasons.
3. Character to Character Reconciliation for all the tables should be done.
4. Unique value must be identified and made available in the new version repost as well.
3. Business Reconciliation - The monthly dumps generated should be available for both existing and new version for reconciliation which includes a summary of financial statements spread and rated by year.
4. User Base – Existing user base and the relevant user access powers should be reconciled between the old and new version. Any exclusions must be notified and approval should be received as per governance process.
3. Any changes in as is migration of Data or DB Schema requires prior approval from competent management authority as per governance process.

3.9 User Management Requirements

1. User authentication must be integrated with Active Directory.
2. User Profile Matrix must be derived approved by bank.
3. A report detailing the relationship between profiles and privileges, which requires approval from the ISO/Risk team before establishing a baseline.
4. The solution should incorporate internal controls for the Maker-Checker functionality in user management profiles, ensuring that each member of the user management team has designated Maker and Checker roles but cannot approve their own actions.
5. Provide training for the user management team.
6. Investigate the possibility of user dormancy settings and the capability to generate related reports.
7. Prior to going live, validation testing must be conducted to ensure the implementation of the approved profile matrix.

 3.10 Parameter Management Requirements

1. Parameter Management module should that incorporate a Maker-Checker process for the creation and modification of parameters.
2. A document detailing the parameter values utilized in the application must be created, which must be approved by both the business and Risk departments.
3. A report designed to track changes in parameter settings must be available.
4. Training to be provided to the parameter management team.
5. The system should have the capability to send email alerts or SMS notifications upon changes to global business and system parameters of application.

__data__.text:
5.0 Regulatory & External dependencies

1. The system is intended for internal credit risk assessment and operates independently of any regulatory or external dependencies.
2. However, it is crucial for the system to adhere to the bank's compliance regulations and ISO standards.

 6.0 Delivery Approach

1. Project delivery is expected to happen in a single phase in waterfall approach.

 7.0 Technology Solutions Landscape

1. Application SECAT score is 2.
2. RiskMatrix who are the authorized implementation partners for CreditLens application will undertake the implementation / upgrade activities.

8.0 Future Roadmap

1. The system should be designed to scale effectively in order to support any new customer segment and its associated rating requirements.

 9.0 Any Other Considerations/Constraints
